alert.note: Alert for Northampton; Virginia Beach (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wakefield (Eastern Virginia and Southern Maryland)
info.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 28 at 2:36PM EDT until September 29 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield
info.description: ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM EDT FRIDAY... ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD WARNING IS CANCELLED... * WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to one foot of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, there is a high rip current risk. * WHERE...In North Carolina, Eastern Currituck County. In Virginia, Virginia Beach, and Northampton County. * WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 11 AM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Friday evening. * IMPACTS...Shallow flooding is expected in the most vulnerable locations near the waterfront and shoreline resulting in a low threat of property damage. Expect up to one foot of water above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks and lawns near the waterfront will experience shallow flooding. Breaking waves of 5 to 7 ft will result in rough surf conditions and a high risk of rip currents. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times. Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases, the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult to return to shore.
